clean_story:
Unseen wear. Silent failure.

"Materials we trust too much" refers to everyday substances we assume will last—until they don’t.
Like a rubber band that snaps after years of stretching.

Concrete cracks.
Not from weight, but from tiny water pockets freezing and expanding inside it—like soda cans bursting in a freezer.
Bridges rely on steel cables, but salt from winter roads eats them slowly, strand by strand.
Plastic pipes in homes weaken from chlorine in tap water, turning brittle over decades.
Even glass isn’t immune: old windows sag because gravity pulls on their uneven thickness.

We trust these materials because they usually work.
But trust fades when a chair leg splinters mid-sit, or a phone screen shatters from a short drop.
The real surprise?
Most failures start invisible—microscopic cracks, chemical shifts, or fatigue from repeated stress.

Fatigue in metals.
The slow betrayal of adhesives.
How time turns reliability into risk.
